Ha ha, I always used traps and then walled myself in. It\'s really the clunkiness of the interface that gets me â€” the fact that I may have to execute hundreds of keystrokes just to build a simple stone tower or enclosure on the surface â€” it\'s quite daunting at times, indeed. Then there come megaprojects...

The main problem for me is that I never really devoted much of my brainpower to planning in DF. That\'s really my fault. When it takes me a year to get things carved out just to deal with the usual influx of immigrants streaming into my fort before winter, the thought of planning some gigantic project and managing all the associated logistics didn\'t strike me as something I particularly wanted to sink my time into. I could have set a much lower population cap and solved that problem, but I was ignorant and lazy.

But over all, Dwarf Fort didn\'t really draw me in, didn\'t offer me a very high level of immersion for a game world supposedly so rife with characters and rich in generated detail. For one thing, I like to play games so I can make things that satisfy others, whether IRL people or in-game characters, and to be honest DF lacks in that area...

Too many people give up on DF too early... it is truly an incredible game.

Personally, what draws me to many games isn\'t just the gameplay, it\'s the 'lore' or 'fluff' of the setting involved (or the settings that the game generates). And in my estimation, on the lore front, DF just doesn\'t have much going for it... I\'ve seen beautiful works of art and writing made by players (I\'ve made one or two myself, not nearly so beautiful though), based on their fortresses\' histories and various statistics pulled up from the Legends window, but really â€” who are the dwarves? Or the elves or the humans or the demons or anyone in the generated settings, for that matter? The world I meet in Adventure Mode is, to put it bluntly, a buggy wasteland of cultureless cities full of samey houses and faceless nobodies with nothing interesting to say to anyone. Legends mode is fun to peek around in for a giggle or a gasp or two or to get a list of kobold names to play around with in my own settings, but after that there\'s really nothing to see unless you have a very active imagination... which I do, but I feel it would be better spent creating worlds of my own design than fleshing out the rather ephemeral randomly generated world of a half-finished video game.

I kind of like the music. It reminds me that time is passing while I\'m playing, and reminds me to look at the clock every once in a while to see how many hours it is past the time I said I\'d stop playing.

To those who are too intimidated to get started, I highly recommend the quickstart guide (http://dwarffortresswiki.org/index.php/DF2012:Quickstart_guide). It really helps you get going on it and make sense of the seemingly limitless menus of actions. The rest of the wiki is also pretty indispensable. I usually have at least five or six tabs of it open at any given time while I\'m playing.
